https://msra.org.au/amsls/

  • On this page https://msra.org.au/amsls/ Can you please decrease the amount of white space between the steering committee and the current projects

Hi Petricia,

Apologies for this one.
 
We have updated the content for the pages "AMSLS Overview" "Key Finding" and the "Health Professionals".
Let me know if this is correct?
https://msra.org.au/amsls/
https://msra.org.au/amsls/key-findings/
https://msra.org.au/amsls/for-health-professionals/

Regarding the header stuffs.
We have updated the "blue bar Page title and submenus" to be fixed when scrolled at certain point.
(If this doesn't work would mind telling us the Operating System that you are using and the size of the monitor).

Hi Joel In addition to the below there are still a few of the original requests that haven't been actioned and a few mistakes. Please can you advise when these will be completed. I have listed below for your convenience. AND there is an urgent fix re incorrect copy being pasted in.
  • Can you add the line separator between the top section and the contact us section. https://msra.org.au/amsls/
  • Please add a "Current projects" section (collapsible) like what we have on the Health Professionals page https://msra.org.au/amsls/for-health-professionals/ and the key findings page https://msra.org.au/amsls/key-findings/ to the overview page https://msra.org.au/amsls/ . It is to sit underneath the steering committee section as per the image below. AND please update the content to include the following;
  • Current Projects content to add to the new collapsible table on the overview page;
Current projects Modifiable lifestyle factors and MS Regardless of who you are, lifestyle choices, such as diet and exercise, can have an impact on your overall wellbeing. For those with MS, finding ways to maintain healthy choices when dealing with fatigue or other physical symptoms at the same time can be challenging. We have several current projects focused on lifestyle factors people can control themselves, including looking into the effects of the "SNAP" factors (smoking, nutrition, alcohol and physical activity) on symptoms severity and quality of life, and what factors influence how much exercise people do and what types of exercise they are choosing to do. Other medical conditions alongside MS Frequently, if you speak to someone with MS they will tell you that MS is not the only medical condition they are dealing with. With MS itself affecting everyone differently, further incorporating a range of other medical conditions in an effective treatment plan becomes incredibly challenging for health care providers. We are looking into the presence of other medical conditions alongside MS, whether they occur before or after MS, which of these have the biggest impact on quality of life, and how they impact common MS symptoms. This information will be beneficial to guide the management of people with MS. Employment With the majority of people being diagnosed with MS at a time where they are just starting to gather momentum in their chosen career, the need to support people with MS to remain happy and productive in the workforce has been a long-term focus for the AMSLS (see key findings). With longitudinal data available, we can examine people's long-term work experiences, including the interplay between disclosure of MS at work, support at work, and the intention to quit, and what more can be done to assist people in reaping the best possible personal and social benefits from active participation in the workforce. Giving you control of your health information - InforMS Over the last few years there has been an increasing number of people wishing to take more control over their own health and wellbeing. The InforMS system is being developed to provide people with the tools to help manage not just MS, but their health in general. Sleep and MS Sleep is essential to our functioning, but MS can adversely impact sleep, which then has flow on effects for other areas of life. We are quantifying how many people have issues with sleep, the factors that might influence sleep, and any resultant impacts on quality of life, daily functioning and other symptoms. The role of MS nurses in maximising health management With MS nurses possessing a level of understanding about MS and its management that is often unmatched by the wider health care community, their availability in many clinics around Australia is an underestimated resource. In collaboration with MS Australia, we are looking into how many people have access to an MS nurse, and how those nurses influence the care of someone with MS. The data will inform service planning for MS nurses around Australia. Feelings of depression With twice as many people with MS affected by anxiety and depression than the general population, we are examining whether people with MS are appropriately treated for depression and whether anti-depressants potentially have a positive effect on the progression of the disease.
  • On the Key Findings page https://msra.org.au/amsls/key-findings/ In the MS and other health conditions the bullet points are not evenly spaced
· On the Key Findings page https://msra.org.au/amsls/key-findings/ In the need for early intervention for progressive onset-MS - the last paragraph should actually be one of the bullet points. There should be 4 bullet points not 3. · On the Key Findings page https://msra.org.au/amsls/key-findings/ In the work attendance section - the last paragraph should actually be one of the bullet points. There should be 4 bullet points not 3.
  • Actually it's the same for the following 3 sections
  • On the Key Findings page https://msra.org.au/amsls/key-findings/ In The keeping cool section - you have pasted in the wrong information. You have actually pasted in instructions and half of the proper content. PLEASE CAN YOU FIX THIS ASAP
  • ON the Health professionals page - something has completely gone wrong with the table - see image

Hi Joel Thank you, however maybe I am not explaining myself very well. Sorry.
  • I am wanting the blue banner and the sub menu to be frozen on the top, however you have only frozen the sub menu. Is there a reason for this? (see image below)
  • On the current survey's page the blue banner and the sub menu are not freezing at all. At the page is very jumpy.
  • On the health professionals page I do not want to see the written out URL in the collaborations table.
    • I would like the University name to hyperlink to the university URL (opening up into another window)
    • I would like the person's name to hyperlink to the URL provided. I do not want to see the URL written in the table at all.
  • If you could please fix the above ASAP.

Hi Petricia,

We have updated a few scripts. We have cleared the site cache as well.  
Let me know if this works for you?

Hi Joel

Thank you for updating the pages. I have just had a quick check and noticed a few things if you could have a look.

I will work through it in more detail but thought you might like to work on the bigger points I have found.

I notice the on some of the pages the sub menu is freezing but the blue banner above it isn't - see screenshot. Please can you have the blue banner freeze as well.

Also this header and sub menu being freezed hasn't been applied to all of the pages i.e. the overview page



On the current surveys page something has happened to the footer - please can this be fixed so it is the same as the other pages



On the Health Professional page - in the table - could the url's not be written out but rather hyperlink the persons name to the url or the university to the university URL.

I'll let you know if I notice anything else.

Thanks

Trish

Hi Trish,

Yes we are all working from home too, for 4+ weeks! It's less of a change for most of us as most of the team work from home. I am missing the 'water cooler' chats though. Oh well, short-term pain as they say : ) 

We will work through the below tomorrow/Wednesday and let you know if we have any questions.
@joel can I ask you to tackle this one please? Thanks!!

Hi Heath
I hope you and your family are staying safe and well. Are you working from home these days? Our whole office moved to working remotely 2 weeks ago, although I am starting to get cabin fever ☹


Wondering if you could please assist. In the attached document I have detailed quite a few edits that I would like made to the AMSLS pages. Please can you have a look and let me know if you have any questions. Hopefully it's all fairly straight forward.


If you could please advise when its been updated so I can advise the research team accordingly.


Thank you so much


Cheers
Trish
